definition: The surgical puncture of the abdominal cavity to remove fluid.
A word formed from the initial letter of the major parts of a compound term.
A condition that has a rapid onset, a severe course, and a relatively short duration.
A radiographic study of the blood vessels after the injection of a contrast medium.
The surgical removal of the appendix.
The abnormal hardening of the walls of an artery or arteries.
Pain in a joint or joints.
The surgical creation of an artificial excretory opening between the colon and the body surface.
A bluish discoloration of the skin caused by a lack of adequate oxygen in the blood.
A physician who specializes in diagnosing and treating disorders of the skin.
The identification of a disease or condition by its signs and symptoms.
The frequent flow of loose or watery stools.
Swelling caused by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in cells, tissues, or cavities of the body.
Pertaining to the interior or lining of an artery.
A disease, structure, operation, or procedure named for the person who discovered or described it first.
A mature red blood cell.
A groove or crack-like sore of the skin; also describes normal folds in the contours of the brain.
An abnormal passage, usually between two internal organs or leading from an organ to the surface of the body.
Pain in the stomach; also known as stomachache.
Inflammation of the stomach lining.
Inflammation of the stomach and intestines.
Any disease of the stomach.
The loss of a large amount of blood in a short time.

The invasion of the body by a pathogenic (disease-producing) organism.
A localized response to an injury or destruction of tissues.
Between, but not within, the parts of a tissue.
Within the muscle.
A torn or jagged wound or an accidental cut wound.
A pathologic change of the tissues due to disease or injury.
A feeling of general discomfort or uneasiness that is often the first indication of an infection or other disease.
Any abnormal condition or disease caused by a fungus.
Any pathologic change or disease in the spinal cord.
Any pathologic change or disease of muscle tissue.
Pertaining to birth.
The study of disorders of the newborn.
Suturing together the ends of a severed nerve.
The study of the ears, nose, and throat.
An examination technique in which the examiner's hands are used to feel the texture, size, consistency, and location of certain body parts.
A pounding or racing heart with or without irregularity in rhythm.
The study of all aspects of diseases.
The bones of the fingers and toes.
A viral infection of the gray matter of the spinal cord.
A prediction of the probable course and outcome of a disease.
Any acute, inflammatory, pus-forming bacterial skin infection.
Discomfort due to the regurgitation of stomach acid upward into the esophagus; also known as heartburn.
The temporary, partial, or complete disappearance of the symptoms of a disease without having achieved a cure.
Objective evidence of disease, such as a fever, that can be observed by the patient and by others.
The act of rotating the arm so that the palm of the hand is forward or upward.
The formation or discharge of pus.
Above or outside the ribs.
Subjective evidence of a disease, such as pain or a headache, that can be felt only by the patient.
A set of signs and symptoms that occur together as part of a specific disease process.

Inflammation of the tonsils.
A wound or injury.
The medical screening of patients to determine their relative priority of need and the proper place of treatment.
Pertaining to a virus.

definition: The large circular cavity in each side of the pelvis that articulates with the head of the femur to form the hip joint.
Originating within another, commonly referring to tissue transplants where the donor and recipient are not genetically identical.
A form of rheumatoid arthritis that primarily causes inflammation of the joints between the vertebrae.
The surgical fusion of two bones to stiffen a joint, such as in the ankle or spine.
A minimally invasive procedure for the visual examination and treatment of the interior of a joint.
Originating within the individual, often referring to the use of one's own tissue in a medical procedure.
The death of bone tissue due to a lack of blood supply, commonly affecting the hip joint.
A procedure to replace damaged or destroyed bone marrow with healthy bone marrow stem cells.
A bulging deposit that forms around the area of a bone fracture as the bone heals.
The abnormal softening of cartilage, often affecting the knee.
A fracture in which the bone is splintered or crushed into multiple pieces.
A fracture that occurs when a bone is pressed together (compressed) on itself, often in the spine.
An inflammation of the cartilage that connects a rib to the sternum, causing chest pain.
A grating sound or sensation produced by friction between bone and cartilage or fractured parts of bone.
A radiographic technique used to measure bone density, typically at the spine and hips.
A piece of intravascular fat that lodges within a blood vessel and causes an obstruction of blood flow.
A type of arthritis characterized by deposits of uric acid crystals in the joints, causing pain and inflammation.
An abnormal enlargement of the joint at the base of the great toe, commonly known as a bunion.
Blood within a joint, often due to an injury or a bleeding disorder.
Pertaining to the formation of blood or blood cells.
A surgical procedure to stabilize broken bones using plates, screws, or other devices placed directly on or in the bone.
An autoimmune disorder that affects children with symptoms of stiffness, pain, joint swelling, and fever.
An excessive outward curvature of the spine, causing hunching of the back.
The surgical removal of a lamina, or posterior portion, of a vertebra.
An abnormal increase in the forward curvature of the lumbar spine, also known as swayback.
Pain in the lumbar region of the spine; commonly referred to as low back pain.
The rounded bony protuberance on each side of the ankle.
The bony structure that forms the upper portion of the sternum.
The five bones that form the palms of the hand.
The five bones that form the part of the foot to which the toes are attached.
A cancer of the blood-forming cells in the bone marrow, causing damage to the bones.
A fracture in which the bone is broken and there is an open wound in the skin.
A physician who specializes in diagnosing and treating diseases and disorders involving the bones, joints, and muscles.
A mechanical appliance, such as a shoe insert, designed to control, correct, or compensate for impaired limb function.
An inflammation of a bone.
A form of arthritis characterized by the breakdown of cartilage and bone in the joints.
A benign bony growth covered with cartilage, commonly occurring near the ends of long bones.
The abnormal softening of bones in adults, typically due to a deficiency of vitamin D or calcium.
An inflammation of the bone and bone marrow, usually due to infection.
Thinner-than-average bone density, often a precursor to osteoporosis.
A condition characterized by a decrease in bone density, causing the bones to become fragile and more likely to fracture.
A type of fracture caused by the weakening of bones due to osteoporosis, commonly involving the hip.
A bone disease of unknown cause characterized by the excessive breakdown of bone tissue, followed by abnormal bone formation.
A fracture that occurs when a weakened bone breaks under normal strain.
A minimally invasive procedure to treat compression fractures of the spine by injecting bone cement into the vertebra.
A specialist in diagnosing and treating disorders of the foot.
An inflammatory disorder causing muscle pain and stiffness, primarily in the shoulders and hips.
A substitute for a diseased or missing body part, such as an artificial limb.
A disease of the spinal nerve roots, resulting in pain and neurological symptoms.
A chronic autoimmune disorder in which the joints and some organs of other body systems are attacked.
A condition in children caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, characterized by defective bone growth.
An abnormal lateral curvature of the spine.
A congenital defect that occurs during early pregnancy when the spinal canal fails to close completely around the spinal cord.
A narrowing of the spinal canal that puts pressure on the spinal cord and nerves.
A fracture in which the bone has been twisted apart, often the result of a severe twisting force.
The forward slipping movement of the body of one of the lower lumbar vertebrae on the vertebra below it.
A degenerative disorder that can cause the loss of normal spinal structure and function.
The partial displacement of a bone from its joint.
The surgical removal of a synovial membrane from a joint.
The 26 small bones that make up the backbone.

Joint
Bursa (a fluid-filled sac that reduces friction in joints)
Cartilage
Rib
Skull
To bind, tie together
Bent, hump

Bone
Curved, bent

The movement of a limb away from the midline of the body.
The movement of a limb toward the midline of the body.
A band of fibrous tissue that holds structures together abnormally, often as a result of injury or surgery.
The lack of muscle coordination during voluntary movement.
Lacking normal muscle tone or strength.
Weakness or wearing away of body tissues and structures, often due to lack of use.
Extreme slowness of movement, often associated with Parkinson's disease.
A condition caused by pressure on the median nerve in the wrist, resulting in pain, numbness, and weakness in the hand.
A disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that is not improved by rest and may worsen with physical or mental activity.
The circular movement at the far end of a limb.
A painful condition that occurs when pressure within the muscles builds to dangerous levels, reducing blood flow.
The movement that bends the foot upward at the ankle.
The distortion or impairment of voluntary movement resulting in fragmented or jerky motions.
A condition of abnormal muscle tone that causes impairment of voluntary muscle movement.
A diagnostic test that measures the electrical activity within muscle fibers in response to nerve stimulation.
Inflammation of the tissues surrounding the elbow, commonly known as tennis elbow.
The study of the design of equipment and workplaces to reduce the risk of injury.
A specialist who works under a physician's supervision to develop exercise programs to promote physical fitness.
Inflammation of the fascia, a band of connective tissue that surrounds muscles.
A debilitating condition characterized by fatigue, muscle, joint, or bone pain, and a wide range of other symptoms.
A harmless fluid-filled swelling that occurs most commonly on the outer surface of the wrist.
A calcium deposit in the plantar fascia near its attachment to the heel bone, causing pain.
Slight paralysis or weakness affecting one side of the body.
Total paralysis affecting only one side of the body.
The protrusion of a part of a structure through the tissues normally containing it.
Abnormally increased motor function or activity.
A condition in which there is diminished tone of the skeletal muscles.
Occurs when inflamed and swollen tendons are caught in the narrow space between the bones within the shoulder joint.
The supply of nerves to a specific body part.
The place where a muscle ends by attaching to a bone or tendon.
Pain in the leg muscles that occurs during exercise and is relieved by rest, due to poor circulation.
A group of genetic diseases characterized by progressive weakness and degeneration of the skeletal muscles.
A chronic autoimmune disease that affects the neuromuscular junction and produces serious weakness of voluntary muscles.
The sudden, involuntary jerking of a muscle or group of muscles.
A specialized soft-tissue manipulation technique used to ease the pain of conditions such as fibromyalgia.
Weakness or slight muscular paralysis.
The surgical suturing of a muscle wound.
Pertaining to the relationship between a nerve and muscle.
A muscle that is slanted or at an angle.
The point where the muscle begins; typically located nearer to the midline of the body or on a less movable bone.
The loss of sensation and voluntary muscle movements in a muscle through disease or injury.
The paralysis of both legs and the lower part of the body.
A physician who specializes in physical medicine and rehabilitation.
Inflammation of the plantar fascia, causing foot or heel pain.
A muscle disease characterized by the simultaneous inflammation and weakening of voluntary muscles in many parts of the body.
The act of rotating the arm or leg so that the palm or sole is turned downward or backward.
The paralysis of all four extremities.
The loss of muscle mass, strength, and function that comes with aging.
A painful condition caused by the muscle tearing away from the tibia.
Myoclonus of the diaphragm that causes the characteristic hiccup sound.
A ring-like muscle that tightly constricts the opening of a passageway.
An injury to a joint, usually involving a stretched or torn ligament.
A condition in which tendons become inflamed or irritated.
The surgical suturing of the end of a tendon to a bone.
The release of a tendon from adhesions.
Inflammation of the sheath surrounding a tendon.
The surgical division of a tendon for relief of a deformity.
A stiff neck due to spasmodic contraction of the neck muscles that pull the head toward the affected side.
A muscle or plane that runs in a crosswise direction.
Two, double
Violent action, twitching

A medication that blocks the action of the enzyme that causes the blood vessels to contract, resulting in hypertension.
A disorder characterized by a decrease in the number of red blood cells or hemoglobin in the blood.
A localized weak spot or balloon-like enlargement of the wall of an artery.
A condition of episodes of severe chest pain due to inadequate blood flow to the myocardium.
A procedure to open a partially blocked coronary artery by flattening the plaque and opening the artery.
A medication that slows coagulation and prevents new clots from forming.
A condition characterized by the failure of blood cell production in the bone marrow.
The loss of the normal rhythm of the heartbeat.
The surgical removal of plaque buildup from the interior lining of an artery.
Hardening and narrowing of the arteries caused by a buildup of cholesterol plaque on the interior walls of the arteries.
A common type of heart arrhythmia characterized by rapid and irregular beating of the atria.
A device that automatically samples the heart's electrical rhythms and delivers an electrical shock if necessary.
A medication that reduces the workload of the heart by slowing the rate of the heartbeat.
An abnormally slow resting heart rate, usually fewer than 60 beats per minute.
An event in which the heart abruptly stops beating or develops an arrhythmia that prevents it from pumping blood effectively.
A diagnostic procedure in which a catheter is passed into a vein or artery and then guided into the heart.
The term used to describe all diseases of the heart muscle.
The surgical removal of the lining of a portion of a clogged carotid artery leading to the brain.
A fatty substance that travels through the blood and is found in all parts of the body.
A condition in which venous circulation is inadequate due to partial vein blockage or leakage of venous valves.
A condition of reduced blood flow to the heart muscle due to a buildup of plaque in the arteries of the heart.
Damage to the heart muscle caused by a thrombus blocking a coronary artery.
The use of electrical shock to restore the heart's normal rhythm.
A medication that stimulates the kidneys to increase the secretion of urine to rid the body of excess sodium and water.
A record of the electrical activity of the myocardium.
The sudden blockage of a blood vessel by an embolus.
A foreign object, such as a blood clot or air bubble, circulating in the blood.
An inflammation of the inner lining of the heart.
Mature red blood cells produced by the red bone marrow.
The oxygen-carrying protein pigment of the erythrocytes.
A condition of an inadequate number of circulating red blood cells due to the premature destruction of red blood cells by the spleen.
The loss of a large amount of blood in a short time.
The process of stopping or controlling bleeding.
A type of cancer characterized by a progressive increase in the number of abnormal white blood cells.
White blood cells that are involved in defending the body against infective organisms and foreign substances.
A decrease in the number of disease-fighting white blood cells circulating in the blood.
A blood disorder characterized by anemia in which red blood cells are larger than normal.
A condition in which the mitral valve does not close properly, allowing blood to flow backward into the left atrium.
A type of cancer in which there is insufficient production of one or more types of blood cells due to dysfunction of the bone marrow.
The occlusion of one or more coronary arteries caused by plaque buildup; also known as a heart attack.
A low blood pressure that occurs upon standing up.
The double-walled membranous sac that encloses the heart.
A form of anemia caused by a lack of the protein that helps the body absorb vitamin B12 from the gastrointestinal tract.
The inflammation of a vein.
A peripheral arterial occlusive disease in which intermittent attacks are triggered by cold or stress.
A potentially life-threatening infection that results from bacteria or other infectious organisms entering the bloodstream.
A genetic disorder that causes abnormal hemoglobin, resulting in some red blood cells assuming an abnormal sickle shape.
An abnormally rapid resting heart rate, usually at a rate of more than 100 beats per minute.
A form of vasculitis that can cause headaches, visual impairment, jaw pain, and other symptoms.
A test performed to evaluate how well blood flows through the coronary arteries during exercise.
A condition in which there is an abnormally small number of platelets circulating in the blood.
A medication that dissolves or causes a thrombus to break up.
The abnormal condition of having a thrombus.
The blocking of an artery by a thrombus.
A blood clot attached to the interior wall of an artery or vein.
A serious and potentially fatal complication of a blood transfusion in which a severe immune response occurs because the patient's blood and the donated blood do not match.
Abnormally swollen veins, usually occurring in the superficial veins of the legs.
A blood clot that starts in a vein.
A rapid, irregular, and useless contraction of the ventricles.
A very rapid heartbeat that begins within the ventricles.

A substance that produces an allergic reaction in an individual.
A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction.
Medications used to treat bacterial infections.
A protein produced by the immune system to identify and neutralize foreign substances.
Medications used to treat fungal infections.
A substance that the immune system recognizes as foreign, prompting an immune response.
The immune response involving the binding of antigens to antibodies.
A condition in which the immune system attacks the body's own cells and tissues.
Rod-shaped, spore-forming bacteria.
Single-celled microorganisms that can cause infections.
A condition, tumor, or growth that is not cancerous and does not spread.
A fungal infection caused by Candida, often affecting the skin, mouth, or genitals.
A malignant tumor that arises from epithelial cells.
A malignant tumor in its original position that has not yet spread to surrounding tissues.
A group of proteins that work with antibodies to destroy pathogens.
An infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
Proteins released by cells that have an effect on the immune response.
A type of herpesvirus that can cause infection in immunocompromised individuals.
A drug that kills or damages cells, often used in cancer treatment.
A breast cancer in its earliest stage, where the tumor has not spread.
Pertaining to the destruction of red blood cells.
A viral infection, also known as shingles, that causes a painful rash.
A type of lymphoma characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.
A virus that attacks the immune system, leading to AIDS.
Antibodies produced by plasma cells that are involved in the immune response.
A drug that suppresses the immune system, often used to prevent organ transplant rejection.
A treatment that uses certain parts of the immune system to fight diseases such as cancer.
The most common type of breast cancer that begins in the milk ducts and invades surrounding tissue.
Proteins produced by the immune system that inhibit virus replication.
Disease of the lymph nodes, often resulting in swollen or enlarged nodes.
A benign tumor formed by an abnormal collection of lymphatic vessels.
Swelling due to an abnormal accumulation of lymph fluid within the tissues.
White blood cells that are integral to the immune system, including B cells and T cells.
A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system.
A diagnostic test used to visualize lymphatic circulation.
A type of white blood cell that engulfs and digests pathogens.
A disease caused by a parasite transmitted through the bite of an infected mosquito.
A term used to describe cancerous cells that have the potential to spread.
A radiographic examination of the breasts to detect cancer.
The spread of cancer from the primary site to secondary locations.
The process by which cancer spreads from one part of the body to another.
A benign tumor composed of muscle tissue.
A malignant tumor derived from muscle tissue.
A group of lymphomas that do not contain Reed-Sternberg cells.
An infection that occurs more frequently in individuals with weakened immune systems.
A type of malignant bone tumor.
An organism that lives on or in a host and gets its food at the expense of the host.
A viral infection that is transmitted to humans through the bite or saliva of an infected animal.
A type of bacteria that is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected tick or mite.
A contagious viral infection preventable by vaccine, also known as German measles.
A malignant tumor that arises from connective tissue.
A group of spiral-shaped bacteria that have flexible walls.
An abnormal enlargement of the spleen.
A group of bacteria that form irregular groups or clusters resembling grapes.
A group of bacteria that form a chain, many of which are responsible for infections such as strep throat.
A severe response to an allergen that affects multiple systems of the body.
Radiation therapy administered at a distance from the body.
A disease caused by a parasite, which can be transmitted from animals to humans.
A highly contagious viral infection, also known as chickenpox.

The form of pneumoconiosis caused by asbestos particles in the lungs.
The condition that occurs when the body cannot get the air it needs to function.
A chronic inflammatory disease of the bronchial tubes.
The incomplete expansion of part or all of a lung.
Abnormally slow rate of respiration.
The permanent dilation of the bronchi.
A medication that expands the opening of the passages into the lungs.
An excessive discharge of mucus from the bronchi.
The visual examination of the bronchi using a bronchoscope.
A contraction of the smooth muscle in the walls of the bronchi.
An irregular pattern of breathing characterized by alternating rapid or shallow respiration followed by slower respiration or apnea.
A group of lung diseases in which the bronchial airflow is obstructed, making it hard to breathe.
An acute respiratory infection in children and infants characterized by obstruction of the larynx, hoarseness, and a barking cough.
A bluish discoloration of the skin caused by a lack of adequate oxygen in the blood.
A genetic disorder in which the lungs and pancreas are clogged with large quantities of abnormally thick mucus.
Difficulty in speaking, which may include hoarseness, weakness, or the cracking of a boy's voice during puberty.
Difficult or labored breathing.
A progressive, long-term loss of lung function, usually due to smoking.
A collection of pus in a body cavity.

Coughing up blood or bloodstained sputum derived from the lungs or bronchial tubes.

The condition of having deficient oxygen levels in the body's tissues and organs.

The visual examination of the larynx using a laryngoscope.

The cavity located between the lungs.
An electronic device that pumps air or oxygen through a liquid medicine to turn it into a mist, which is then inhaled by the patient via a face mask or mouthpiece.
A physician with specialized training in the diagnosis and treatment of diseases and disorders of the ears, nose, throat, and related structures of the head and neck.
A contagious bacterial infection of the upper respiratory tract that is characterized by recurrent bouts of a paroxysmal cough, followed by breathlessness and a noisy inspiration.
An inflammation of the pharynx.
The excess accumulation of fluid in the pleural space.
An inflammation of the pleura.
A sharp pain that occurs when the inflamed membranes rub against each other with each inhalation.

The accumulation of air in the pleural space causing a pressure imbalance that prevents the lung from fully expanding or can cause it to collapse.
The diagnostic measurement of physiological activity during sleep.
The accumulation of fluid in lung tissues, especially the alveoli.

An external monitor placed on the patient's fingertip or earlobe to measure the oxygen saturation level in the blood.
The presence of pus in the pleural cavity.
An inflammation of the sinuses.
A potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts.
A recording device that measures the amount of air inhaled or exhaled and the length of time each breath takes.
An abnormally rapid rate of respiration.
The surgical puncture of the chest wall with a needle to obtain fluid from the pleural cavity.

The surgical creation of a stoma into the trachea to insert a tube to facilitate breathing.
A procedure in which an incision is made into the trachea to gain access to the airway below a blockage.
An infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, usually attacking the lungs.

Pain or discomfort in digestion, commonly known as indigestion.

Any deviation from the normal positioning of the upper teeth against the lower teeth.
The passage of black, tarry, and foul-smelling stools.

An excessive accumulation of fat in the body.

A drug that causes temporary loss of bodily sensations.
A medical professional who specializes in administering anesthesia.
An eating disorder characterized by a false perception of body appearance.
Mental health disorders characterized by excessive fear or worry.
A developmental disorder characterized by challenges with social skills, repetitive behaviors, and communication.
Temporary paralysis of the seventh cranial nerve causing facial drooping on one side.
An ultrasound study of the carotid artery to detect plaque buildup or blockages.

A bruising of brain tissue as a result of a head injury.

An abnormal fear of being in narrow or enclosed spaces.
The mental processes of perception, memory, judgment, and reasoning.
A deep state of unconsciousness in which the individual cannot be awakened.
A violent shaking up or jarring of the brain, typically caused by injury.
A collection of blood trapped in the tissues of the brain.
An acute condition of confusion, disorientation, and agitation.
A severe form of alcohol withdrawal involving sudden and severe mental or nervous system changes.
A false belief or opinion that is strongly held despite evidence to the contrary.
A slowly progressive decline in mental abilities, including memory, thinking, and judgment.
The thick, tough, outermost membrane of the meninges.
A learning disability characterized by substandard reading achievement due to the brain's inability to process symbols.
The process of recording the electrical activity of the brain through the use of electrodes attached to the scalp.
An inflammation of the brain, usually caused by a viral infection.
An anesthetic injected into the epidural space surrounding the spinal cord.
A chronic neurologic condition characterized by recurrent episodes of seizures.
A condition in which a person acts as if they have a physical or mental illness when they are not really sick.
A sensory perception experienced in the absence of an external stimulus.
A stroke caused by the rupture of a blood vessel in the brain, leading to bleeding.
A condition in which excess cerebrospinal fluid accumulates in the ventricles of the brain.
A condition of abnormal and excessive sensitivity to touch, pain, or other sensory stimuli.
A type of stroke that occurs when the flow of blood to the brain is blocked.
A lowered level of consciousness marked by listlessness, drowsiness, and apathy.
An inflammation of the meninges of the brain and spinal cord.
The congenital herniation of the meninges through a defect in the skull or spinal column.
A headache characterized by throbbing pain on one side of the head and sometimes accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light or sound.
A progressive autoimmune disorder characterized by inflammation that causes demyelination of the myelin sheath.
An inflammation of the spinal cord.
A radiographic study of the spinal cord after the injection of a contrast medium.
A sleep disorder consisting of sudden and uncontrollable brief episodes of falling asleep during the day.
Chemical substances that make it possible for messages to cross from the synapse of a neuron to the target receptor.
A disorder characterized by recurrent, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) or repetitive behaviors (compulsions).
A sudden, intense feeling of fear that comes without warning.
Abnormal behaviors such as nightmares or sleepwalking that occur during sleep.
An abnormal sensation, typically tingling or pricking ('pins and needles'), caused chiefly by pressure on or damage to peripheral nerves.
A chronic degenerative central nervous disorder characterized by fine muscle tremors, rigidity, and a slow or shuffling gait.
A disorder of the nerves that carry information to and from the brain and spinal cord, producing pain, loss of sensation, and inability to control muscles.
A mental health condition that's triggered by a terrifying event, either by experiencing it or witnessing it.
A potentially serious or deadly disorder in children that is characterized by vomiting and confusion, often after a viral infection.
A mental disorder characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized thinking, and abnormal motor behavior.
Pain along the sciatic nerve, which radiates from the lower back down the leg.
A sudden, uncontrolled electrical disturbance in the brain.
A serious brain injury resulting from forcefully shaking an infant or toddler.
A brief loss of consciousness caused by a temporary decrease in blood flow to the brain, commonly known as fainting.
An involuntary, rhythmic muscle contraction leading to shaking movements in one or more parts of the body.
A condition characterized by sudden, intense, severe lightning-like pain due to an inflammation of the fifth cranial nerve.
Burning sensation.

Shaken together, violently agitated.

category: Ch11 Special Senses: The Eyes and Ears

definition: A dimness of vision or the partial loss of sight, especially in one eye, without detectable disease of the eye.
category: Ch11 Special Senses: The Eyes and Ears

definition: A condition in which there is an error of refraction causing improper focus of light on the retina.
category: Ch11 Special Senses: The Eyes and Ears

definition: A condition in which the pupils are unequal in size.

definition: A condition in which the eye does not focus properly because of uneven curvatures of the cornea.

definition: The loss of transparency of the lens that causes a progressive loss of visual clarity.

definition: A nodule or cyst, usually on the upper eyelid, caused by obstruction in a sebaceous gland.

definition: An electronic device that bypasses the damaged portions of the ear and directly stimulates the auditory nerve.

definition: Inflammation of the conjunctiva, usually caused by an infection or an allergy.

definition: An inflammation of the lacrimal gland that can be caused by a bacterial, viral, or fungal infection.

definition: Double vision.

category: Ch11 Special Senses: The Eyes and Ears

definition: The inversion of the edge of an eyelid.
category: Ch11 Special Senses: The Eyes and Ears

definition: A form of strabismus in which one or both eyes turn outward.
category: Ch11 Special Senses: The Eyes and Ears

definition: A radiographic study of the blood vessels in the retina of the eye following the intravenous injection of a fluorescein dye as a contrast medium.

definition: A group of diseases characterized by increased intraocular pressure that causes damage to the retinal nerve fibers and the optic nerve.

definition: Blindness in one-half of the visual field.

definition: A pus-filled lesion on the eyelid resulting from an infection in a sebaceous gland.
category: Ch11 Special Senses: The Eyes and Ears

definition: A vision defect in which light rays focus beyond the retina, also known as farsightedness.
category: Ch11 Special Senses: The Eyes and Ears

definition: A contagious inflammation that causes painful blisters on the eardrum.
category: Ch11 Special Senses: The Eyes and Ears

definition: Inflammation of the uveal tract affecting primarily structures in the front of the eye.

definition: Inflammation of the cornea.

category: Ch11 Special Senses: The Eyes and Ears

definition: An involuntary, constant, rhythmic movement of the eyeball.

definition: The visual examination of the fundus (back part) of the eye with an ophthalmoscope.

definition: A precancerous skin growth that occurs on sun-damaged skin.
A genetic condition characterized by a deficiency or the absence of pigment in the skin, hair, and irises of the eyes.
The partial or complete loss of hair, most commonly on the scalp.
The surgical reduction of the upper and lower eyelids by removing sagging skin.
A large blister that is usually more than 0.5 cm in diameter.
A soft, raised, pink, or red vascular birthmark.
A cluster of connected furuncles (boils).
An acute, rapidly spreading bacterial infection within the connective tissues.
A normal scar resulting from the healing of a wound.
A noninfected lesion formed by the buildup of sebum and keratin in a hair follicle.
The removal of dirt, foreign objects, damaged tissue, and cellular debris from a wound to prevent infection and to promote healing.
An inflammation of the skin.
Profuse sweating.
Atypical moles that can develop into skin cancer.
A large, irregular area of purplish discoloration due to bleeding under the skin.
A form of persistent or recurring dermatitis usually characterized by redness, itching, and dryness, with possible blistering, cracking, oozing, or bleeding.
Redness of the skin due to capillary dilation.
Abnormal redness of the entire skin surface.
A widespread rash, usually in children.
A condition in which there is widespread scaling of the skin, often with pruritus, erythroderma, and hair loss.
Inflammation of the hair follicles.
Large, tender, swollen areas caused by a staphylococcal infection around hair follicles or sebaceous glands.
A swelling of clotted blood trapped in the tissues.
The presence of excessive body and facial hair in women, usually occurring in a male pattern.
A group of hereditary disorders characterized by dry, thickened, and scaly skin.
A highly contagious bacterial skin infection that commonly occurs in children.
An abnormally raised or thickened scar that expands beyond the boundaries of the original incision.
Any skin growth, such as a wart or a callus, in which there is overgrowth and thickening of the skin.
A malformation of the nails in which the outer surface is concave or scooped out like the bowl of a spoon.
A chronic abnormal condition that is characterized by the accumulation of fat and fluid in the tissues just under the skin of the hips and legs.
A benign, slow-growing fatty tumor located between the skin and the muscle layer.
A discolored flat spot that is less than 1 cm in diameter.
A type of skin cancer that occurs in the melanocytes.
A condition characterized by patches of darker skin on the face, especially the cheeks.
A severe infection caused by Group A strep bacteria that enters the body through a wound.
The edges of a toenail curve inward and cut into the skin.
A fungal infection of the nail.
A benign, superficial wart-like growth on the epithelial tissue or elsewhere in the body, such as in the bladder.
A small, raised red lesion that is less than 0.5 cm in diameter.
An acute or chronic infection of the skin fold around a nail.
An infestation with lice.
Small pinpoint hemorrhages that are less than 2 mm in diameter.
An open ulcerated wound that is caused by prolonged pressure on an area of skin.
Itching associated with most forms of dermatitis.
A common skin disorder characterized by flare-ups in which red papules covered with silvery scales occur on the elbows, knees, scalp, back, or buttocks.
The appearance of multiple purple discolorations on the skin caused by bleeding underneath the skin.
Producing or containing pus.
The surgical removal of excess skin and fat from the face to eliminate wrinkles.
A chronic condition of unknown cause, characterized by tiny red pimples and broken blood vessels.
A skin infection caused by an infestation with the itch mite.
An autoimmune disorder in which the connective tissues become thickened and hardened, causing the skin to become hard and swollen.
An inflammation that causes scaling and itching of the upper layers of the skin or scalp.
A malignant tumor of the scaly squamous cells of the epithelium.
An autoimmune disorder characterized by a red, scaly rash on the face and upper trunk that also attacks the connective tissue in other body systems.
A fungal infection that can grow on the skin, hair, or nails.
Hives, an itchy wheal caused by an allergic reaction.
Small, hard skin lesions caused by the human papillomavirus, commonly known as warts.
A condition in which a loss of pigment-producing cells results in patches of white skin.
A small bump that itches, often appearing as a symptom of an allergic reaction.
Excessively dry skin.
Cold.
Skin.
Skin.
Sweat.
Hairy, rough.
Fat, lipid.
Black, dark.
Fungus.
Fingernail, toenail.
Hair.
Pus.
Wrinkle.
Sebum.
Rash, hives.
Dry.
A rare chronic disease characterized by abnormal enlargement of the extremities caused by excessive secretion of growth hormone after puberty.
A condition that occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough of the hormones cortisol or aldosterone.
Inflammation of the adrenal glands.
An abnormality of electrolyte balance caused by the excessive secretion of aldosterone.
A hormone that helps control blood pressure by reducing the amount of water that is excreted.
A hormone that works with the parathyroid hormone to regulate calcium levels in the blood and tissues.
The steroid hormones produced by the adrenal cortex.
A corticosteroid that has an anti-inflammatory action, regulates the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins, and helps maintain blood pressure.
A congenital form of hypothyroidism that, if not treated soon after birth, causes arrested physical and mental development.
A condition caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol.
A condition caused by insufficient production of the antidiuretic hormone or by the inability of the kidneys to respond to this hormone.
A group of metabolic disorders characterized by hyperglycemia resulting from defects in insulin secretion, insulin action, or both.
A life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus, primarily type 1, that occurs when the body cannot use sugar as a fuel source because there is not enough insulin.
Damage to the retina as a complication of uncontrolled diabetes.
Mineral substances, such as sodium and potassium, normally found in the blood.
A hormone that stimulates the sympathetic nervous system in response to physical injury or mental stress.
A hormone secreted by the ovaries that is important in the development and maintenance of the female secondary sex characteristics.
